meta.title: System Design Interview – Memory Deck (v1)
meta.description: Spaced-repetition cards for interview steps, tradeoffs, and core building blocks.

decks.name: Foundations: Steps, Scale, Tradeoffs
decks.description: Your default interview flow + core concepts you should recall instantly.

cards.prompt: What are the first 3 things to do at the start of a system design interview?
cards.answer: Clarify requirements (functional + non-functional) → define constraints (SLOs, cost, compliance) → estimate scale (QPS, data size, growth).

cards.prompt: What are common non-functional requirements (NFRs) to ask about?
cards.answer: Latency SLO, availability target, consistency needs, throughput, durability, cost, security/privacy, compliance, observability.

cards.prompt: Rule of thumb: how do you estimate bandwidth from QPS?
cards.answer: Bandwidth ≈ QPS × avg response size (and consider peak vs average).

cards.prompt: When do you add a cache? Name 3 triggers.
cards.answer: Read-heavy workload, expensive computation/DB queries, hot keys/hot data, need to reduce latency or backend load.

cards.prompt: Name 3 cache invalidation strategies and one risk.
cards.answer: TTL/expiry, write-through/write-behind, explicit invalidation (publish/subscribe). Risk: stale reads / inconsistency / thundering herd.

cards.prompt: Replication vs sharding — what problem does each solve?
cards.answer: Replication: availability + read scaling + durability. Sharding: write scaling + dataset size beyond one node.

cards.prompt: CAP theorem in one sentence (practical version).
cards.answer: Under network partition, you must trade off between consistency and availability (you can’t fully guarantee both).

cards.prompt: Why use a message queue in system design?
cards.answer: Decouple services, buffer spikes, smooth workloads, enable async processing, improve resilience with retries/DLQ.

cards.prompt: Idempotency: what is it and where is it critical?
cards.answer: Same request can be processed multiple times with same result. Critical for retries: payments, order creation, at-least-once consumers.
